text:
SPEAKER: With us today, we
have Professor Haim Mendelson. Welcome. Professor Mendelson is the
Kleiner Perkins Caufield

& Byers professor of
electronic business and commerce and management
at the Stanford Graduate

School of Business. His work has been published
in many leading journals, and he's been a consultant
to leading high technology

companies, stock exchanges,
financial services companies, management consulting companies
and industrial companies.

Professor Mendelson,
what a lineup that was. Thank you so much for
being with us today. And we're really looking
forward to today's session.

HAIM MENDELSON: Yeah,
thank you very much, Robyn. It's great to be
with all of you.

Today, we're going to discuss
business models and disruption.

And the plan of the
webinar is first of all,

to talk about, "What
is a disruption?" It's a concept that people talk
a lot about, but very often,

don't define. So we'll define what it is. We'll see how it relates to the
concept of a business model.

And we'll then go into
what is a business model.

We'll put together a
framework for thinking about business models. We'll apply the framework.

We'll think about some
of the key trade-offs in designing a business model.

We'll then talk about a number
of different types of business models with a number
of applications,

and we'll discuss how
some of these examples have resulted in a
response to disruptions.

So that's the plan. So let's start with that plan. So basically, "what
is disruption"

is kind of our first question. And essentially, disrupt
is a change in technology,

in customer preferences,
in competition or in regulation that
necessitates a major business

model change. So that's how business
models and disruptions are related to one another.

So whenever we have
a big change that requires a big change
in our business model,

we call this a disruption. And if we think about the
business model as house,

a disruption is like an
earthquake that requires us to redesign the house. Sometimes, part of the house.

Sometimes, we need to
rebuild the entire house.

So what is a business model? Because when I
define disruption, I use the concept
of a business model.

So again, if you go to
the analogy of the house, before you build the
house, hopefully, what you

want to have is a
blueprint that describes the architectural
structure of that house.

A business model is a very high
level architectural structure

that describes the
structure of a business. So it's essentially a
theory or a blueprint

of the business itself. And just like a mathematical
model or a high level

blueprint, it is stylized. It focuses on the key
elements of the business model

and the relationships
among them. It doesn't describe everything. It just goes at a
very high level.

The business model
concept is used both for startups, where
it provides an organizing

framework for building
the business model or for established companies
that are facing a disruption,

and they need to rethink
their business model and redesign the business
model, and to some extent, go

a bit into startup mode. So both of these are
cases, where we really

need to think carefully
about our business model. And as I said, it's
a little bit like

the architectural, high
level architectural blueprint of a house.
And it has three key points. The first three key elements.

The first element is
the value creation model that describes who are our
customers, how we are going

to create value for
these customers, and how we are going to
deliver that value to them.

So that focuses on the customer. The second room of that
house is the profit model

that describes how we're going
to extract some of the value that we create in the process
of running the business.

It describes the revenue
model, the cost structure and the key drivers
of profitability.

The roof of the
house is the logic of the business
model, which basically

describes what our goal is. Sometimes, we put more
emphasis on profits. Sometimes, we put more
emphasis on growth.

Sometimes, we have a non-profit. So we have totally
different objective. We want to save the planet.

All of these are
goals that drive the logic of the business.

And the logic of the business
basically answers the question, "why do we think that we are
going to achieve that goal?"

So when we design
a business model, we think about how we're
going to create value.

We think about how we're going
to extract some of that value. We think about the interaction
between these two elements,

and we think about how that
interaction is going to help us achieve our objectives.

So these are the key
things we think about when we build the business model.

One of the things that
we need to keep in mind is that there is
typically tension

between the value creation
model and the profit model. And the tension is people
tend to not focus on it.

And it's actually pretty
important to think about it when we build the
business model because we need to realize that some
of the decisions that we

make that create more value
may actually hurt our profit.

An interesting example of that
is the example of Facebook. So when Facebook
was established,

they kind of described what
they're trying to do and what--

so this picture is
actually a picture that appeared on
the Facebook Hoodie

that people had
in the year 2010. So they would wear a hoodie. And inside that
hoodie, they would

have this picture that
describes the value creation model of Facebook. So the idea is that we want
to make the internet more

open than connected using
essentially the stream here, which is the newsfeed,
and the social graph

and the platform that enables
outside developers to tap into our system.

So this is the way
Facebook described itself. And importantly, they said,
our value creation model

is really almost perfectly
aligned with our profit model.

And in fact, when Facebook
was first established at Harvard University-- it's one of the few startups
that started at Harvard, not

at Stanford-- what they did was they made
sure that they can actually

make money before they grow. So basically, they made
sure that each time they added a server in
another University,

they made sure they're going to
have enough advertising revenue to cover the cost
of that server.

So from their
perspective, they thought about the value creation model
and the profit model together.

And one could argue that the two
elements of the business model

are very well aligned. But of course, over
time, as it turned out,

there are some cracks
in that alignment. And essentially, what happens is
that because Facebook's profit

model is based on advertising-- so Facebook funds itself
through advertising revenue.

What happens is that
think they have to think not only about their users.

They need to think as
carefully and sometimes, more carefully about the
paying customers, who

are the advertisers. So they have to design
the business model. So that there will be a
high level of engagement.

So that people will stay
engaged with the platform. So people will come
back to Facebook.

And indeed, they've managed
to keep a very high level of engagement over a
very long period of time

because that was a metric
that they focused on. But if you want
people to be engaged,

the question is,
how do we do that? And we measure all kinds of
metrics that drive engagement.

And as it turns out, content
which is more polarizing.

Content that makes people angry. Content that makes people
agree with more extreme views

tends to be more
engaging in that sense than content, which is
a little more friendly.

And the result of that
is that when you just apply the Facebook algorithms
what you tend to do

is really amplify
some negative trends.

So the result of that is
that actually, to make money to support the profit model,
what we're going to do

is actually adjust the
value creation model so that users will not be
as well off as they would

be without that profit model. And the reason is, of
course, that the profit model

is driven by the advertisers. And the value creation model
is driven by the users.

So we really need to
satisfy the advertisers, and that's not the same
as satisfying the users.

So the result of that is tension
between the value creation model and the profit model.

Now, if we think about-- so
people say, Mark Zuckerberg, is he an angel? Is he the devil?

We need to take that
back, and think about what is the business model?

Why are they doing that? And in the case
of Facebook, they have a very effective
business model

from a profitability
point of view. What you see on this chart
is the average revenue

per user per quarter
for Facebook, where the blue bars are
averages in the United States.

You can see that in the
fourth quarter, which is the peak quarter, Facebook
is making more than $60
per user per quarter. So think about this.

If you think about
Netflix, Netflix is making approximately
in revenue about $48 per user per quarter.

So Facebook is making
an average on each user more money than
Netflix is making.

And Netflix has to make
all of these investments in creating content and
spend billions and billions of dollars on new
content all the time.

And Facebook, by just
putting people together, is able to create
much more money.

So basically, Facebook is
executing a business model that calls for satisfying the
advertisers because that's

where the revenue
is coming from, and it's not the
only business model that can work for
content and interaction.

So compare that to a
company called Substack where content providers
can publish their content

and create a direct
connection with their users.

And in the case of
Substack, you can see in this picture, their growth.

So it's growing. The growth rate is very nice
at least until the end of '22. We don't have data
following 2022.

And the way it works
then is that you can subscribe to a
content provider,

and they can send you
some content for free. And if you want, you pay
them typically $5 a month

or $10 a month, and they
send you premium content only for subscribers.

And Substack is taking a
percentage of that revenue. So this is a
business model, where

there is a much better alignment
between what the value creation model tells us to do for the
users in what the profit model

tells us to do for our profits. There's very good alignment
because our paying customers

are exactly the users for
whom we're creating the value. But if you look at
the numbers here--

so this is in thousands. So by the end of 2022, they
managed to get 2 million

paying subscribers. Compare that to Facebook
that has 3 billion users that

generate revenue. So you have to make a choice
when you build your business

model, you can choose between
the Facebook business model. Free to the users
but less alignment.

Or the Substack business model-- end users great alignment, but
the numbers are much smaller.

And what Facebook
is doing essentially is selecting the
free business model.

And that's one of the things
that makes it most profitable. So when we select
our business model,

we need to think carefully about
the trade-off between value creation and profit and
where we want to be.

And it's up to us to
make that decision. Some companies start in
one way and go to the other

as a result of disruption. And a good example
of that is Netflix. So Netflix started as a
company where you rent DVDs,

and you pay subscription. So just like Substack
is a subscription model

and it creates great
alignment between the users

and the company because if the
user doesn't like the content, they quit.

So everything is
driven by the value that we create for the users. And you can see in
this chart the growth

of the number of DVD
subscribers that Netflix had when it started.

It was only in
the United States. So by the end of
2010, the number

grew to approximately 18 million
subscribers, which at the time was considered a great number.

Now of course, late the first
years of the 20th century,

gradually, we've seen
an increasing emphasis on streaming. And that presented a potential
disruption for Netflix.

And what you see in this chart-- I expanded the time frame. And you can see on the
left, the brown bars

represent the number
of DVD subscribers, which peaked in 2011.

And starting in 2009
roughly, Netflix

started providing
to its users also streaming content, which
initially was provided for free

and then became paid content. And you can see in 2011,
kind of the transition

from an emphasis on DVDs and
an emphasis on streaming.

So this is what a technology
driven disruption looks like, right? So what we see here
is a big change

in the business
model from one that's based on distribution
centers, US postal office

service, physical
DVDs to one that's based on everything-is-digital.

We start creating
our own content. And you can see that the
number of DVD subscribers

is going down sharply. And during that
period of disruption, big business model change,
what happened to Netflix

was that it was almost destroyed
because the transition from one

model to the other
model was not smooth. And to the point
where they decided

to separate the two models. They dramatically
raised the price.

Most of the users had to pay
and they loss a lot of users. So it took them a year
or two to figure out

how to stabilize
the business model. They've managed to do that,
and you can see the blue bars

kind of rising very nicely. And you can also
see the green bars they started as part
of that process.

Once you have
streaming technology, you can actually expand
the business model to other countries. Initially to specific
countries and then

to the rest of the world. And this picture
ends in 2019, right?

So Netflix became
the streaming giant, the leader of the streaming
based business model.

And let's look at
what happened later. So you can see this
chart kind of takes us

from 2013 to the present. And you can see the
number of users,

the subscribers is
growing very nicely, but then it's becoming flat. It's actually growing more than
nicely during the pandemic,

but then it flattens out. And in fact, there
was actually a decline in the number of subscribers
in the United States.

So at the end of
2022, Netflix decided to change its
business model again,

and to switch from a
business model that's based only on subscriptions
to a business model that mixes

subscriptions and advertising. And as we have seen
before, this has

big implications for the way
we think about the business because with an
advertising-based business

model, we need to satisfy,
not only the subscribers but also, the advertisers.

Today, the effect is small. The revenue they have
from a advertising 2022

is something like
half a billion, but it's expected
to increase quickly.

And at that point, they
will face the same dilemmas that we've talked
about for Facebook.

Let's talk briefly about the
business model development process. How do we develop
a business model?

Let's think about
going to space. So in the United States, kind of
the agency that opened up space

to the world, at least in
the United States, was NASA.

Essentially, government
funded a entity that developed the technology
and kind of space exploration

and so on. And a slogan that
was formed when

they had problems
with Apollo 13 was, "Failure is not an option." So for NASA, whenever
they sent a satellite,

they kind of worked very
hard to make sure in advance that everything will go right.

Of course, it didn't
always happen. But the idea was we are
putting a lot of effort

to make sure that nothing
will go wrong because failure can be catastrophic.

Let's compare that
to the approach, which is taken by SpaceX.

By the way, you see here how
much money NASA was getting.

Started this in 2006. Of course, in the
'60s and '70s, there was a lot of funding from
NASA to the space missions

that they had then. But I wanted to start
in 2006, and the reason is that want to compare
them to SpaceX, which got

its initial funding in 2006. And of course, SpaceX has
a very different approach.

And the approach of
SpaceX is that "Failure

is the only option." It's not that failure
is not an option. Failure is the only option. And basically, if you
compare NASA's funding

to SpaceX funding, what
you see on the black chart is from 2006 to this year,
the cumulative funding

that went to NASA-- which
is roughly about $20 billion a year. And what you see in the green
bars, which are hardly seen

here, is the funding to SpaceX. So you can see that
SpaceX is used.

And in 2006, you can't
even see it in this chart, but it's a very small number.

But you see here that SpaceX
funding was only a fraction--

a very small fraction
of the funding of NASA. But you could argue,
this chart is unfair

because some of the
money that came to SpaceX was not from people who funded
it but came from NASA itself.

So let's add to
the NASA numbers-- I'm sorry. To the space numbers the
money that they got from NASA.

And you see it in this chart. So the green bars are
funding for SpaceX.

And the small-- you
can hardly see them. The brown additions to the
chart are the amounts of money

that went from NASA to SpaceX. So you can see that SpaceX,
they're a very lean operation.

And of course, they have
a very different approach. Their approach is that
failure is the only option.

We fail and fail and fail. And by failing, we
create the information

that enables us to develop our
product and our business model until we succeed.

And a good example is their
most recent major launch.

And you see here the
beginning of the launch of their current product,
which is Starship.
So Starship is the space--

so the rocket. And then there is
the actual capsule. And that's the one that's
going to go to Mars.

By the way, it's
going to serve them before they go to Mars to ship
a lot of satellites to Earth.

And I'm sorry-- to orbit. And it has a very
large number of--

it can take a lot
of those satellites. So dramatically, increases the
profitability of the company.

And in April of this year,
they had a major launch. Kind of the first major test
launch of this combination.

And you can see, they
started, and then it went out.

And essentially,
what you see here is what they call Rapid
Unscheduled Disassembly or RUD.

In short, RUD means
that it blew up, right? So the spaceship,
the whole thing. And it's interesting
to see the reaction

of SpaceX employees, who
are kind of following what

happened. And what you see here--
they're kind of celebrating. They're cheering up,
and they're so happy,

and the spaceship blew up. Why are they so happy? And in the same event,
you could actually see.

We don't have it here. Elon Musk is smiling. He's happy. And why are they happy? Because the failure gave
them a lot of information

that increases the likelihood
that their next launch will be successful. So the approach that
SpaceX is taking

is an approach that's
based on failing to learn. And typically, when we
develop a new business model,

we have to assume that it's
so new that we don't really know for sure whether or
not it will be successful.

And as a result of that, we
need to plan for these failures as learning events.

We need to iterate what
the business model. Test it out. Systematically test element by
element of the business model.

And that's how we create
a viable business model. Let's look at a
business model types.

I call them archetypes there
are many types of business models in the world,
but there are four types

that cover a significant
percentage of many

of the business models that
we can actually see in action. And I'm going to show
it to you by looking

at the same industry. Same industry. You have multiple business
models, and all of them can be successful.

And I'm going to use
the lodging industry

and why did they
choose the lodging industry because actually,
the lodging industry you have large chains like
Marriott, which combine

many different business models. So within the same
company, you can actually have multiple business models.

And this is a brand of Marriott. There are about 30
brands of Marriott.

Each of brands of
Marriott actually represents a totally
different business model.

So what they have is
basically a segmentation of the market into multiple
business models, which

have multiple value
creation models that create attract different
types of customers

and have different
profit margins. The first brand want to
look at is the second one

in this picture-- is Ritz-Carlton. And basically, Ritz-Carlton,
what you see here

is the website, Ritz-Carlton
in Half Moon Bay, which is just a few
miles from Stanford.

And Ritz-Carlton
is a luxury brand. And the lowest price room you
can get during this period here

in Ritz-Carlton is $700. But actually, it
goes up dramatically.

So you can get a room for
$700, $800, $2000, $4,000.

And the question
is, why do people pay $4,000 $2,000 for a room? They basically pay for used bed.

That's what they're getting. So why are people
willing to pay so much? The reason they're
willing to pay so much

is really a key element of
the Ritz-Carlton business model, which was invented about
70 years ago when they started

before they had computers. And they decided that
what they're going to do is based their
business model on what

they call "customer intimacy,"
which means that we deliver the best solutions to specific
customers or customer segments

by tailoring our products
or services to satisfy unique or highly
targeted customer needs.

And how do they do that? So basically, they did early on
what most hotel chains do today

using computers, which
is to basically record

the preferences of
their customers. And I'm looking here
at the questions.

I see these are
technical questions. I'm not going to address them.

Yeah, it's all
technical questions. But if people have
questions, then I'll

try to address them
if they fit in.

So the basic idea--
we record information about our customers, and
we use that information

to give them increasingly
better quality of service. So for example,
historically, the first time

you went to a Ritz-Carlton,
they would give you three types of cookies.

And in the morning, they would
watch which cookie did you eat.

And they would record
which cookies you ate. So now, they know
which cookies you like.

And the next time you
go to Ritz-Carlton, they give you just the cookies
that you like because now, we

know what you like. If you want to go to a certain
type of restaurant, you ask,

well, how do I find a
Japanese restaurant? They record that.

And next time you go to any
Ritz-Carlton, they'll say, well, we have a great Japanese
restaurant in this city.

Here it is. If you rearrange the
room, they will actually record how you
rearrange the room,

and they'll try to match
it next time you go there, unless it's a really unusual
way to rearrange the room.

So the idea is that
we collect information about our customers.

And as a result of that, we can
give them high quality service.

As a result of the
quality of service, the customers come back to us.

When they come back, they
give us yet more information, so we can give them
even better service.

So what happens is that
frequency drives information,

which drives quality of
service, which drives loyalty, which drives frequency.

So we have virtual cycle
of customer intimacy. This is the logic
of customer intimacy

that we see in many, many
different types of business models. Let me go to another
Marriott business model.

Actually, the first one
of the luxury brands is called EDITION.

So EDITION is a
design-based hotel,

which is an example of what I
call a product or in this case,

service leadership. And basically, it's a business
model that was designed.

The hotels are designed
by famous designer. And the designer tries to make
give you a unique experience,

exquisite looking hotel. And the idea here
is to impress you

with the quality of
the hotel itself. You see here.

They said, "The world's
hottest hotel brand." So that's kind of what a
product leadership is about.

It's kind of interesting. When the designer
was asked, what is so special about EDITION?

Why do we need to
pay so much for it? He said, what
distinguishes Apple phones

from everybody else? You can't quite put
your finger on it, but you're in a
special place, right?

So a little bit like
the Apple of hotels. And Apple, of course,
is another example
of a product leadership. And definition.

If we go to the definition
of product leadership,

"we create value for
customers by generating a stream of products
or service innovation."

So it's the innervation of the
service that drives customers to us.

The next kind of
archetype is one that I call
operational excellence,

where we deliver a standard
product or service that meets our customers'
needs at a low cost,

or it provides superior
functional performance. And in the case
of Marriott, this

is done by their
Fairfield brand. So the Fairfield
brand, the idea here is that it's a very
functional hotel.

But the idea is that we give
you functionality and low cost. And we achieve that
through standardization.

So there's a standard
template essentially that's used to design the hotel. The hotels don't have--

the human-based customer
service is minimal. You can buy things at
the vending machine.

There is standard breakfast. Buffet that you can get. It's reliable, clean,
functional, low price.

The idea is if that's
what you're looking for, Fairfield is for you.

And what you can see here
that what they advertise is the beauty of simplicity. It's simple.

It's functional. It does the job. It's low cost. And standardization
is a key feature

that enables us to do that. The fourth archetype
that I want to talk about

is value chain coordination,
where we create value by coordinating different
elements of the value chain.

So we have different
components of the value chain, and what we do is
coordinate them. And the simplest example of
that-- there are many examples,

but I'm going to go with the
simplest one, which is Airbnb.

So in the case of Airbnb,
it's a marketplace. So a marketplace is
the simplest form

of value chain coordination. And of course, Airbnb does
not own the properties.

It simply coordinates
the value chain. It matches hosts
and guests, and to

enables the hosts to provide
spare space that they have

or space that they
bought in some cases, where you have a professional
host to the guest.

And it enables the guests
to get the type of space

that they are looking for as
an alternative to a hotel. And we kind of think about,
in the case of Airbnb,

how do they create value? So Airbnb, because it
coordinates hosts and guests,

it really has two
types of customers. And it needs to satisfy
both of them to work.

To satisfy the hosts,
what they do is basically, the host get extra revenue
from resources that

otherwise, would stay idle. So the value proposition
for the host is clear.

The value proposition
for the guest varies. So if you look at the
results of surveys

of why people go to stay at
their Airbnb, the number one

reason they do it is
less expensive compared to a comparable hotel room.

It's not always less expensive. Some Airbnbs are
very, very expensive. But on average,
they are about 30%

less expensive than a
comparable hotel room. And that's what attracts
most people to Airbnb.

The second factor is location. So hotels, , by their economics
requires them to be close

to conference centers, places
where lots of people stay. And the hotel
itself is a building

that accommodates hundreds,
sometimes more people. So as a result of that,
they're concentrated

in specific parts of a city. And Airbnb is spread
throughout the city

wherever people have space. So as a result of that, if you
look for a specific location,

which is not the
conference center, not a central location,
what will happen

is that you're much more likely
to find that location on Airbnb

than in a hotel. And that's an advantage
that a lot of people prefer.

And then the experience
is a great experience. Sometimes, the host
helps you shows you the city around and
so on and so forth.

Easy to use. Sometimes, you want to
have your own kitchen. You want to stay in a house. You come with the family.

Uniqueness of the units. So all of these are
factors that the business

model enables you to do. When we think about the
uniqueness of the units, Airbnb is increasingly
emphasizing that.

You can find all kinds
of spaces on Airbnb, which are unlikely to be
available in the hotel.

And you can even find
an igloo on Airbnb. They're in this list. There are 11 igloos that I
identified, and about half

of them have Wi-Fi
if you're interested. And one of the key advantages
of the value chain coordination

business model compared
to a standard hotel is that it's much more
scalable because you

don't have physical resources. Airbnb doesn't have to
own these properties.

So when you get started. This is a problem that
you need to address. And in the course,
in the online course,

we actually spend
some time thinking about how to address
that problem. So you can see early
on, Airbnb's increasing.

But of course Marriott
is much, much bigger in terms of the amount
of money that people pay

to stay there in the aggregate. But by 2017, Airbnb
matched Marriott.

And by 2019, it exceeded
Marriott by far, right?

Because of the advantages
of its business model. And it's interesting
to actually look

at the effect of a disruption on
the operation of that business model. And the obvious disruption
that happened following 2019

was COVID-19, right? So COVID-19 caused
a major disruption

to the travel industry. And it affected negatively
both Marriott and Airbnb.

And you can see here. 2020. The gross bookings on
Airbnb fall sharply.

The gross bookings on
Marriott fall sharply. If you compare that to what
happened in the industry

at large, you can that it was
even worse for the industry

at large in terms of the number
of people that went to hotels. But the interesting thing is
that Airbnb is recovering much,

much faster than Marriott. And the reason is that it has
a much more resilient business

model. During COVID-19 itself,
during the disruption, Airbnb was able to switch
the type of space that

was available from
central city locations to other types of locations
because basically, Airbnb

doesn't have to
build those spaces. It's just that you have
different types of hosts that satisfy demand that evolves
as a result of the disruption.

In the case of
Marriott, of course, they can't instantaneously
build a new hotel,

where people want to go. So the result of that, they
have to lay off people.

They can't respond. And you can see that
following the disruption-- so hopefully, COVID-19
is over by now.

So you can see Airbnb going
up very, very quickly, and Marriott, and the rest
of the industry recovering

but much more slowly because
they have to hire people. They have to train them.

It's not that easy to
shift the types of hotels that you want to have. So it's a much, much slower
and more painful process.

And again, that's reflected
in the economics of Airbnb. You can see here
the number of nights

booked on Airbnb
in the blue line and the gross booking value
in Airbnb on the brown line.

Of course, there's a
lot of seasonality. So you can see it going up
and down within each year. But the general trend is
way up much more than--

actually, it
continues to increase faster than it did
before the disruption

as a result of having a pretty
good business model, which is the value chain
coordination business model.

And so this is an example
of how previously we

talked about the
technology disruption. Here, we have an example
of how a disruptive event--

in this case, COVID-19-- affects the business model. And Airbnb has not only
responded to COVID 19

but is now changing
its business model to a business model that
focuses much more on people

who want to work from anywhere. So work from home is a
phenomenon that's decreasing,

but it's not going down to zero. More and more people work
from many, many more different

locations. And Airbnb is adjusting
its business model to accommodate that.

And that's reflected
in their financials. And again, because it's a value
chain coordination business

model, it can do it
much more effectively than a more traditional
business models.

Let's look at another
example of how technology

changed the business model. And they look at another value
chain coordination business

model, which is
called Be My Eyes. So Be My Eyes-- essentially, it's a
network, which has users.

And the users are people who
are blind or vision impaired.

And basically, they have
an app on their phone. And today, they have about
half a million people

using it in that way. So there are a large number
of people all over the world. And on the other
side of the network

are volunteers who help them. So if I'm blind and I want to
see what shirt I'm wearing,

I can point my phone camera to
the shirt that I'm looking at.

And I'll click on
the app, and that will send the image to a
person who volunteered to help.

One of the 7 million people. And that person
will see the shirt and will tell me
on the phone, this

is a shirt with a striped
shirt with blue stripes and white stripes.

Is that the shirt you want? And I can say, OK, I
actually want another shirt. And I point my phone and so on.

So it's a value chain
coordination business model or a
marketplace, which has

on one side,
vision-impaired people. On the other side,
volunteers that

use the person's
phone as their eyes. And they just tell them,
here is what it is.

Now, what is the
technology disruption? So technology
disruption in this case

is a large language
models or ChatGPT. So the way it works today
is still experimental.

They call it Be My AI
instead of Be My Eyes.

And the way that works is well,
I want to wear that shirt. I point my camera at the
shirt, and it takes the image

of the shirt, but instead
of going to a volunteer. It's going to OpenAI's ChatGPT,
which looks at the image

and interprets it. And instead of a
person saying it, it's the large language model
that tells me on the phone,

this is a shirt. It has these stripes. These stripes. So you don't need
the 7 million people.

Now of course, you still need
them because the large language model is not perfect.
But what happens? You can see here. You kind of point your camera.

You get the reply. And if you want, you
can ask a volunteer

because sometimes
it's not clear. Sometimes, not accurate. So you can still
ask for a volunteer, but what will happen over time
is as the application learns

more and more, it will be
increasingly more accurate. So the number of volunteers
that you will need

will decline
gradually over time. And today, the kind of manual
application with volunteers

is going to decline because
it can be done automatically.

So the total change in
the business model that's driven by change in technology.

Of course, AI technology is
affecting many other companies. And since we talked
about Facebook,

it's kind of interesting to talk
about Facebook in that context. So Facebook has made great
strides through the use of AI

and through the use of
large language models. And one of the kind of
disruptions that Facebook

has faced was the
disruption from Apple, where Apple has changed its
privacy policies so that they

don't automatically share
app data with Facebook, which creates a big
problem for Facebook.

And people have
said, Facebook, it's really going to be pretty
disruptive to Facebook

because most of their
users use it on the phone. And they lose that phone data.

What are they going to do? And indeed, Facebook
for a period of time,

has had a hard time actually
adjusting to that change. But it developed AI systems
to actually use its own data

and data it has available
to it much more effectively. As a result of
that, not only have

they been able to respond
to the change from Apple they've been able to do better.

And in fact, a few
days ago they actually announced their results for
the third quarter of 2023.

So they had $34 billion
of revenue, which is like four times Netflix.

And it was 23% higher
than a year ago. And they did all of that after
laying off 22,000 employees.

So they managed to do
that by using AI and data

that they had access to do
actually better than they could do with the data that they got
directly from Apple's operating

system, iOS. The other thing they've
done is, of course, reduce their cost dramatically
by both traditional means,

which are layoffs
that we talked about, and using tools to improve
their own internal productivity.

So basically, when we reduce
cost in traditional ways,

the effect is usually
not permanent. It's a temporary effect because
over a few years, what happens?

Everything comes back to
the way it used to be. But when we reduce costs
through the use of technology,

in this case, the use
of AI, these effects are permanent because the
technology is there to help us.

And in the case of Facebook,
the effect was dramatic. So we combine the
effect of the layoffs.

And the use of AI was that
expenses a percent of revenue declined from 80% of revenue
a year ago to 59% of revenue

in the last quarter. And their profit almost
tripled from last year,

from $4.4 billion to
$11.6 billion, all right?

And they are
continuing to use AI to support their advertisers. Remember, their kind of
main paying customers

are advertisers. So they use generative AI,
their large language model,

to actually help
first of all to help. So they have a system
called Advantage+ that helps

advertisers do better
matching for their ads. But now, they are
going a step further

and help them actually
create the ads. So what happens here is
that they use technology

to actually improve their
business model and respond,

in this case in a positive way
to a technology disruption.

Let me look. We have a few questions here. So let me look at the questions. So there's a question
about Airbnb,

whether COVID was a disruption. So by our definition,
COVID was definitely a disruption for
Airbnb's business model

because it was a big exogenous,
external event that forced them to change their business model.

So they didn't change
fundamentally what they do, but they made big changes
in their business model.

So it's certainly an example
for disruption for Airbnb.

So there's a question. "You have mentioned that you
will describe four business model archetypes. Will you summarize these later?"

So later, maybe now. So we can go back and
summarize them again. So basically, we introduced
them through the examples,

but this slide
summarizes all four. So the first one is
customer intimacy,

where we deliver best solutions
to specific customer segments through the use
of customer data.

Product service
leadership, where we innovate products or services.

Operational excellence, where
we reduce cost, or increase functionality for
product or service

homogenously for a large number
of customers in value chain coordination,
which is what we've

seen in the case of Airbnb and
Be My Eyes, where what we do

is we coordinate elements
of the value chain. And a special case of
that is a marketplace.

So the question I
have here is, "How

is SpaceX develop
its business model? Has it been the same
from the start?"

So I think that fundamentally,
SpaceX business model

has been based on the idea,
and we didn't have time to talk about it. But since we have the question,
I'm going to go into it.

So the basic idea of the
SpaceX business model is to build reusable rockets.

And the idea is that if you
want to be able to go to Mars and do it in a
systematic way, you

can't do it if you can use your
rockets only once because that would be like developing
jet service between San

Francisco and New
York City, where you can use the plane only once. I mean, it's just
economically not viable.

So the basic idea was to
develop a solution, where

the rockets are reusable. Initially, of course, the
rockets were not reusable. So they continue to
iterate, iterate, iterate.

Drive costs down. Create reusable rockets. And the business model
has evolved from there to,

"OK, so how do we use
these reusable rockets?" Then they added to it a
very important element,

which is Starlink, which is
when we send out these rockets, we have customers that pay us
to ship a payload to space.

But we can always fill them
up with our own payload, which

are these satellites that
are going to be in space, and provide internet service
to people who do not otherwise,

have good internet service. And there are lots of them. Lots of examples. We won't go into them. So SpaceX-- again, we've
seen a gradual evolution
of the business model.

So the question here,
"Is Facebook value chain coordination business model?" Absolutely.

Facebook is primarily a value
chain coordination based business model,
which coordinates, ,

first of all interactions
between users and other users, and between users and
content providers,

and between users
and advertisers. So it's a multi-- it's a very complex value chain
coordination business model.

But it's certainly a good
example of that business model.

The question is, "Are
these business model

archetypes exhaustive?" No, they are not there
are many business models that combine these.

And there are business
models that are outside this list, of course. They are not

represent a large enough

give us a good start.

So when you look at
the business model, you say, OK, this

but they do also this,

and they do also this. So it helps us get

But it's certainly
not exhaustive. And with that, I think I covered
